remarks.para: The collection of objects (the ) is accessed through the control's property.

The control automatically creates a collection of objects for you when you set the property to an appropriate data source. The objects created actually are instances of one of the following classes that inherit from : or class.
To format the data display, set the property of the class to one of the formatting values. For more information about valid formatting values, see Formatting Types and Custom DateTime Format Strings.
You can also create your own set of objects and add them to the . When you do so, you must set the of each column style to the of a to synchronize the display of columns with the actual data.

block.para: Always create objects and add them to the before adding objects to the . When you add an empty with a valid value to the collection, objects are automatically generated for you. Consequently, an exception will be thrown if you try to add new objects with duplicate values to the .

remarks.para: When one of the derived classes is instantiated by a control, the class created depends on the of the associated with the object. For example, a with its set to System.Boolean will be associated with a . To determine the type of any , use the method.

To create your own column classes, you can inherit from . You might want to do this in order to create special columns that host controls, as exemplified by the class, which hosts the control. For example, you can host an control to show pictures in columns, or you can create your own user control to host in the column.

The functionality of the shouldn't be confused with that of the . Whereas the contains the properties and methods appropriate to creating a data table's schema, the contains the properties and methods related to the appearance of an individual column on the screen.
If a row contains a , the text displayed in the column can be set with the property.

The class also allows you to specify the behavior of a column while its data is being changed. The and methods temporarily suspend the drawing of the column while large updates are being made to the column's data. Without this functionality, every change in every cell of the grid would be immediately drawn; this could be distracting to the user and a performance liability.
Several methods allow monitoring of the column as it is edited by the user, including the and events.
Most of the properties and methods of the class are tailored to controlling a column's appearance. But a few, such as the and allow you to examine and change the value in a specified cell.

summary.para: Specifies the appearance, text formatting, and behavior of a control column. This class is abstract.

remarks.para: When you create an instance of a , the following properties are initialized.

summary.para: In a derived class, initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: To create a new , you must first get the for the data source of the table to which the column will be added. See the CurrencyManager and BindingManager for details on getting specific CurrencyManager objects for a form.
From the , you can then get the for the that will supply the data for the column.
When you create an instance of a , the following read/write properties are initialized.

summary.para: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified .

Docs.param: A that provides the attributes for the column.

remarks.para: The method is used by the when the method of the method returns false. In that case, the column value is rolled back to its previous value.
The must end any editing operations before returning. Use the method to accomplish this.
The method of the control indirectly invokes if its parameter is set to true.

summary.para: When overridden in a derived class, initiates a request to interrupt an edit procedure.

Docs.param: The row number upon which an operation is being interrupted.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.Windows.Forms.HorizontalAlignment Alignment { set; get; }

summary.para: Gets or sets the alignment of text in a column.

remarks.para: For more information about handling events, see [<topic://cpconEventsOverview>].

summary.para: Occurs when the property value changes.

remarks.para: When many changes are made to the appearance of a control (whether the changes are in the attributes of the column or the data displayed by the control), you should invoke the method to temporarily freeze the drawing of the control. This results in less distraction to the user, and a performance gain. After all updates have been made, invoke the method to resume drawing of the control.

summary.para: Suspends the painting of the column until the method is called.
Throws an exception if the does not have a valid data source, or if this column is not mapped to a valid property in the data source.

Docs.param: A to check.

remarks.para: When called, the method allows the control to show a pencil in the row header indicating the row is being edited.

summary.para: Informs the that the user has begun editing the column.

Docs.param: The that hosted by the column.

MemberSignature.Value: protected abstract bool Commit (System.Windows.Forms.CurrencyManager dataSource, int rowNum);

summary.para: When overridden in a derived class, initiates a request to complete an editing procedure.

returns.para: true if the editing procedure committed successfully; otherwise, false.

Docs.param: The for the .
The number of the row being edited.

remarks.para: Use this method to determine when a further action is required in a derived class. For example, this method is overridden by the to hide the .

summary.para: Notifies a column that it must relinquish the focus to the control it is hosting.

remarks.para: This property is called by a when its property changes. This property is required because any child controls hosted by a must be added to the control's ControlCollection.

summary.para: Gets the for the column.
Gets the for the column.

MemberSignature.Value: protected virtual void Edit (System.Windows.Forms.CurrencyManager source, int rowNum, System.Drawing.Rectangle bounds, bool readOnly);

remarks.para: Typically, the method sites a control onto the grid at the location of the cell being edited.

summary.para: Prepares a cell for editing.

Docs.param: The for the .
The row number to edit.
The bounding in which the control is to be sited.
A value indicating whether the column is a read-only. true if the value is read-only; otherwise, false.

The row number in this column which is being edited.
The in which the control is to be sited.
A value indicating whether the column is a read-only. true if the value is read-only; otherwise, false.
The text to display in the control.

MemberSignature.Value: protected abstract void Edit (System.Windows.Forms.CurrencyManager source, int rowNum, System.Drawing.Rectangle bounds, bool readOnly, string displayText, bool cellIsVisible);

remarks.para: Typically, the method sites a control onto the grid at the location of the cell being edited.

The row number in this column which is being edited.
The in which the control is to be sited.

remarks.para: When many changes are made to the appearance of a control (whether the changes are in the attributes of the column or the data displayed by the control), you should invoke the method to temporarily freeze the drawing of the control. This results in less distraction to the user, and a performance gain. After all updates have been made, invoke the method to resume drawing of the control.

summary.para: Resumes the painting of columns suspended by calling the method.

remarks.para: This method is called when the user presses ALT+0 to allow a column to enter the appropriate null value. For example, when called on a , the appropriate value is inserted into the column.
The has no default behavior. When inheriting from , override the method to enter null in a column.

summary.para: Enters a into the column.

remarks.para: For more information about handling events, see [<topic://cpconEventsOverview>].

summary.para: Occurs when the column's font changes.
Gets the height of the column's font.

MemberSignature.Value: protected virtual object GetColumnValueAtRow (System.Windows.Forms.CurrencyManager source, int rowNum);

remarks.para: If the data source for the column is a , use the or events to determine when a row or column value has changed.

summary.para: Gets the value in the specified row from the specified .

Docs.param: The containing the data.
The row number containing the data.

summary.para: When overridden in a derived class, gets the minimum height of a row.

returns.para: The minimum height of a row.

MemberSignature.Value: protected abstract int GetPreferredHeight (System.Drawing.Graphics g, object value);

remarks.para: The will usually be invoked from a mouse down event to resize a column's height for a long string.

summary.para: When overridden in a derived class, gets the height used for automatically resizing columns.

returns.para: The height used for auto resizing a cell.

Docs.param: A object.
An object value for which you want to know the screen height and width.

MemberSignature.Value: protected abstract System.Drawing.Size GetPreferredSize (System.Drawing.Graphics g, object value);

remarks.para: Use to determine the width a column should resize to, given a particular string or numeral.

summary.para: When overridden in a derived class, gets the width and height of the specified value. The width and height are used when the user navigates to using the .

returns.para: A that contains the dimensions of the cell.

Docs.param: A object.
An object value for which you want to know the screen height and width.

summary.para: Gets the for the column.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string HeaderText { set; get; }

remarks.para: The property is typically used to display a caption that is different from the value when the value isn't easily understandable. For example, you can change the to "First Name" when the value is "FName".

summary.para: Gets or sets the text of the column header.

remarks.para: For more information about handling events, see [<topic://cpconEventsOverview>].

summary.para: Occurs when the property value changes.

remarks.para: The method is typically called after an editing operation is interrupted. For example, you can call the method when implementing the method.

summary.para: Redraws the column and causes a paint message to be sent to the control.

remarks.para: The comparison used to match the to the data member is case-insensitive.
This is used to render the data in the indicated data member whenever the data source matches the one indicated by the property of the that contains this column style.
The property is usually set to the of a .

summary.para: Gets or sets the name of the data member to map the column style to.

remarks.para: For more information about handling events, see [<topic://cpconEventsOverview>].

summary.para: Occurs when the value changes.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string NullText { set; get; }

remarks.para: The class's property determines if a column can contain null values.

summary.para: Gets or sets the text that is displayed when the column contains null.

summary.para: Occurs when the value changes.

remarks.para: The for a column is set using the method of the . See the constructor for an example of using the to create a new .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool ReadOnly { set; get; }

remarks.para: Make a column read-only if it contains a primary key or if its value is generated automatically (as when the object's property is set to true).

Similar read-only properties exist on other classes, each allowing more control over the access to data. For example, the control can be set to read-only mode by using its property; the also has a property, and the class has a property for restricting data updates.

summary.para: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the data in the column can be edited.

remarks.para: For more information about handling events, see [<topic://cpconEventsOverview>].

summary.para: Occurs when the property value changes.

remarks.para: If you create a class that derives from , you will often use the derived class to host a control that is used to edit data. You should override the method to release any references to the control in order to free system resources. For example, the derived class uses this method to release the reference to the hosted .

summary.para: Allows the column to free resources when the control it hosts is not needed.

remarks.para: You typically use this method if you are either creating a designer for the , or creating your own control incorporating the .

summary.para: Resets the to its default value, null.
